chav1961.purelib.json

Class JsonSerializer<T>

  • java.lang.Object
    • chav1961.purelib.json.JsonSerializer<T>
  • Type Parameters:
    T - T - class to serialize.

    public abstract class JsonSerializer<T>
extends Object

    This class is a JSON serializer/deserializer for different classes. It supports both primitive and referenced Java classes. Sources and targets for JSON serialization can be:

    • character arrays
    • CharacterSource and CharacterTarget implementations
    • JsonStaxParser and JsonStaxPrinter streams

    To speed up serialization/deserialization, class can generate byte code on-the-fly for requested classes (see GettersAndSettersFactory). Reading/writing to char arrays is limited by it's current size. Reading/writing to other source/targets has no any limitations.

    Rules for serialization/deserialization are:

    • any primitive types and String entities can be serialized
    • any arrays of previously described types can be serialized
    • any public instance fields of previously described types from the class instance can be serialized
    • any non-public instance fields of previously described types from the class instance can be serialized if the class implements Serializable or Externalizable interface
    Since:
    0.0.2
    Author:
    Alexander Chernomyrdin aka chav1961
    See Also:
    CharacterSource, CharacterTarget, JsonStaxParser, JsonStaxPrinter, GettersAndSettersFactory, chav1961.purelib.streams

      • serialize

        public abstract int serialize(T instance,
                              char[] content,
                              int from,
                              boolean reallyFilled)

        Serialize class instance to char array

        Parameters:
        instance - instance to serialize
        content - array to write serialized for to
        from - start position inside the array
        reallyFilled - true - really fill content, false - calculate size required only
        Returns:
        new start position in the array. Negative number means that char array length is too small to keep serialization, and it's absolute is full array length to store serialization

      • deserialize

        public abstract T deserialize(JsonStaxParser reader)
                       throws ContentException,
                              SyntaxException

        Deserialize class instance from reader

        Parameters:
        reader - reader to deserialize instance from
        Returns:
        instance deserialized
        Throws:
        ContentException - on any instantiation problems
        SyntaxException - in any syntax errors in the JSON

      • deserialize

        public abstract int deserialize(char[] content,
                                int from,
                                T[] result)
                         throws SyntaxException

        Deerialize class instance from char array

        Parameters:
        content - array to deserialize instance from
        from - start position inside the array
        result - array to receive instance deserialized. Must contain at least one element
        Returns:
        new start position inside the array
        Throws:
        SyntaxException - in any syntax errors in the JSON
